awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Development of decentralized anomaly detection for industrial facilities
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of technology that will aid digital controllers in detecting and identifying anomalies in industrial systems. Every industrial sector relies on industrial control systems to function. There is significant commercial interest in technologies which reduce the risk of unplanned failure and improve worker knowledge and operational effectiveness through data-driven insights. Existing solutions share common issues around cybersecurity, cost of installation, workforce knowledge on how to use the solution, and the ability to explain unusual observations. By separating from the cloud and focusing on the autonomous and explainable capabilities of the technology, technicians using this technology may be able to perform their jobs rapidly and more effectively without needing be experts in artificial intelligence / machine learning (AI/ML) themselves. Adopting a “plug-and-play” approach will reduce the barrier to entry for deploying analytics on smaller systems, thereby enabling better awareness of facility states and avoiding facility degradation before it becomes urgent. The technology will also benefit underrepresented entities in the current industrial solutions landscape as the solution may reduce the cost of implementation and the infrastructure redesigns. This technology may reduce industrial downtime and improve overall facility and process reliability, thereby reducing costs of US-based manufacturing.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of an autonomous, edge-based analytics technology for decentralized and scalable fault detection. The core technology is an efficient software which can detect faults in an industrial control system autonomously using on a very small computational footprint.  Such a solution will make the deployment of analytics possible even for small-scale systems which are normally overlooked in analytics initiatives. The proposed technology autonomously collects, analyzes and builds analytical AI models based on data from digital industrial assets in the field and then uses these models to continuously monitor for signs of anomalous behavior corresponding to equipment degradation or malfunction, all with no connection to the cloud. The software is derived from kernel-based regression methods, such that all predictions and decisions can be directly introspected and explained. These capabilities are paired with a simple and easy-to-understand user interface which can be interactively used to identify the root signals driving a given alarm system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to perform customer discovery and understanding for advanced AI technology intended to be deployed to monitor critical infrastructure. The intent of this technology is to enable decentralized monitoring and alarming of critical infrastructure. The core philosophy of this approach was that existing tools and technologies requiring cloud/external connectivity typically require significant adjustment of security postures and cybersecurity best practices. This technology sought to transfer the machine learning process to the “edge”, totally local to the equipment, such that critical infrastructure can enable persistent monitoring without compromising on cybersecurity. This project allows the team to thoroughly explore multiple industries sectors, having exploratory conversations with these customers to understand customer behavior, value proposition, as well as understand where the technology might best fit.

Through the interviews with different sectors, the team verified that the intellectual merits of this technology had overall great value propositions. Compared to existing solutions, these value propositions are: 1) it is operational on any industrial device, requiring a minimum of computational resources (4-core CPU and 1 GB of main memory), 2) it utilizes strictly existing sensors and data sources to function, not requiring the installation of any new equipment, 3) it can operate for extended periods without significant human intervention, and most importantly, 4) the machine learning methods utilized are explainable.

The team identified that the problems the technology is solving are frequently measurable – being in line with lean startup methods – and straightforward enough that a potential market could be understood by lean startup methods. The team has identified strong potential markets, and is working to use lean startup methods to better understand what specific opportunities in these markets look like.

The EL currently serves as full-time CEO of the startup, Sentinel Devices LLC. The company has secured a paid pilot project and has secured non-dilutive funding. PI (TL) has gained better understanding of industrial process and pain points, and has integrated these information and knowledge into her research and teaching.
